yggdrasil/Building-with-Go.title: Building with Go
yggdrasil/Building-with-Go.content:
This refers to compiling .go programs to .exe or other binary
On Windows:
go build main.go 
Compiles it and its dependencies
If you would like to compile your entire project package
go build 
Does that!
If you would like to cross compile
 
set GOOS=linux 
set GOOS=amd64 
go build 
If you are on PowerShell:
$env:GOOS="linux" 
$env:GOARCH="amd64" 
go build 
If you would like to specify the output filename
go build -o outputfilename

yggdrasil/Chemoproteogenomics.title: Chemoproteogenomics
yggdrasil/Chemoproteogenomics.content:
Chemoproteogenomics is an interdisciplinary field that combines chemoproteomics and genomics to gain a deeper and more comprehensive understanding of biological systems, particularly in the context of disease like cancer.1
Hereâ€™s a breakdown of what that means:


genomics: This involves studying the entire set of an organismâ€™s genes (its genome), including genetic variations like mutations.2 In the context of chemoproteogenomics, this often involves analyzing whole exome sequencing (WES) and RNA sequencing (RNA-seq) data to identify genetic alterations.3


Chemoproteomics: This is a powerful chemical biology technique that uses small molecule probes to identify and characterize protein-small molecule interactions on a global, proteome-wide scale. Itâ€™s particularly useful for:


Identifying functional amino acids: For instance, it can pinpoint specific cysteine residues that are highly reactive or susceptible to modification, which often indicates their importance for protein function.4


Assessing druggability: It can help determine which proteins or specific sites on proteins are â€œdruggableâ€ â€“ meaning they can be targeted by small molecule therapies.5


Understanding drug mechanisms: By identifying what proteins a drug interacts with, it can shed light on how the drug works and any potential off-target effects.6




How Chemoproteogenomics Integrates Them:
The â€œgenomicsâ€ part informs the â€œchemoproteomicsâ€ part. For example, in cancer, genetic mutations can lead to altered proteins, including those with new or modified cysteine residues.7 These â€œgain-of-cysteineâ€ mutations are particularly interesting because cysteine residues are often targets for chemical probes and drugs.8
Chemoproteogenomics platforms aim to:


Identify genetic variants: By analyzing genomic data, researchers can pinpoint mutations that lead to changes in protein sequences, such as the acquisition of new cysteines.9


Map the functional landscape of these variants: Using chemoproteomics, they can then assess the reactivity, druggability, and functional significance of these altered or newly acquired protein sites.10 This helps understand how genetic variations translate into changes at the protein level and how these changes might impact disease or drug response.11


Guide therapeutic discovery: By linking genetic information to protein function and druggability, chemoproteogenomics can accelerate the development of precision therapies that specifically target the unique molecular characteristics of a disease.12


In essence, chemoproteogenomics helps bridge the gap between genetic understanding of disease and the functional consequences at the protein level, ultimately guiding the discovery of new therapeutic strategies.13

yggdrasil/Download-PLINK-2.title: Download PLINK 2
yggdrasil/Download-PLINK-2.content:
Download Plink2
mkdir -p ~/bin && source ~/.profile
wget -P ~/bin/ s3.amazonaws.com/plink2-assets/plink2_linux_x86_64_latest.zip
unzip ~/bin/plink2_linux_x86_64_latest.zip -d ~/bin/
rm -v ~/bin/plink2_linux_x86_64_latest.zip
plink2 --version

yggdrasil/MAVE-Assays.title: MAVE Assays
yggdrasil/MAVE-Assays.content:
MAVE assays â€” short for Multiplexed Assays for Variant Effect â€” are experimental techniques used to measure the functional impact of many genetic variants at once. Instead of testing one mutation at a time, MAVE lets researchers test thousands (or more) of variants simultaneously in a high-throughput way.
ğŸ”¬ What does a MAVE assay do?
It assesses how each possible mutation (or variant) in a target gene or protein affects its function, expression, or interaction. This helps in:


Understanding which mutations are damaging or benign


Predicting disease risk


Creating better functional annotations for genes



ğŸ§ª How does it work (simplified)?


Mutant Library: You create a large library of gene variants (e.g., all possible single-nucleotide changes).


Introduce into Cells: You introduce these into cells or organisms in a pooled format.


Functional Selection or Screening: You apply a selection pressure or perform a functional assay that lets you distinguish variants (e.g., by growth, binding ability, fluorescence).


Sequencing: You use next-generation sequencing to see which variants enriched or depleted under the condition.


Scoring: You calculate a functional score for each variant â€” showing how â€œgoodâ€ or â€œbadâ€ it is compared to the wild-type.



ğŸ§  Why are MAVE assays powerful?
They allow:


Systematic mapping of genotypeâ€“phenotype relationships


Study of variants of unknown significance (VUS) in clinical genetics


Testing drug effects on mutant proteins


Benchmarking and improving computational variant effect predictors



ğŸ” Example Techniques
Some common forms of MAVE assays:


Deep Mutational Scanning (DMS): Often used on proteins


Saturation Genome Editing (SGE): Used to test all variants at a locus using CRISPR


Massively Parallel Reporter Assays (MPRA): Used to test variants in regulatory DNA

yggdrasil/PLINK-(Complete).title: PLINK (Complete)
yggdrasil/PLINK-(Complete).content:
For some useful PLINK Code, see Download PLINK 2
PLINK is a popular open-source genetic data analysis tool primarily used in genome-wide association studies (GWAS) and population genetics. Itâ€™s super efficient for handling large-scale genotype data, especially in .ped/.map or .bed/.bim/.fam formats.
ğŸ”¹ What it does:

Data filtering (e.g., MAF, HWE, missingness)
Association testing (case/control, quantitative traits)
LD pruning and clumping
IBD/IBS analysis
PCA for population structure
File format conversion (e.g., VCF â†’ PLINK)

ğŸ”¹ Common PLINK commands:
plink --bfile data --assoc         # Basic association test
plink --bfile data --make-bed      # Convert to binary PLINK format
plink --bfile data --pca           # Principal component analysis
ğŸ”¹ Why people love it:

Itâ€™s lightweight and fast
Easy to script in pipelines
Plays well with R, Python, and other tools like REGENIE, BOLT-LMM, and PRSice

If youâ€™re starting with GWAS or QC, PLINK is pretty much your go-to tool.
coding bash biology

yggdrasil/Pandas-(Complete).title: Pandas (Complete)
yggdrasil/Pandas-(Complete).content: For quick syntax help, see Pandas Cheat Sheet (General Use)

yggdrasil/Pandas-Cheat-Sheet-(General-Us.title: Pandas Cheat Sheet (General Use)
yggdrasil/Pandas-Cheat-Sheet-(General-Us.content:
1. Importing and Creating DataFrames
import pandas as pd
 
# From CSV / Excel
df = pd.read_csv('file.csv')
df = pd.read_excel('file.xlsx')
 
# From dictionary
df = pd.DataFrame({'name': ['Alice', 'Bob'], 'age': [25, 30]})

2. Inspecting Data
df.head()         # First 5 rows
df.tail()         # Last 5 rows
df.info()         # Summary of columns, non-nulls
df.describe()     # Stats for numeric cols
df.shape          # (rows, columns)
df.columns        # Column names
df.dtypes         # Data types

3. Selecting Data
df['col']                     # One column
df[['col1', 'col2']]          # Multiple columns
df.iloc[0]                    # First row (by position)
df.loc[0]                     # First row (by index)
df.loc[0, 'col']              # Cell by label
df.iloc[0, 1]                 # Cell by position
 
df[df['age'] > 25]            # Conditional selection

4. Modifying Data
df['new'] = df['age'] + 1     # New column
df.rename(columns={'old': 'new'})    # Rename column
df.drop('col', axis=1)        # Drop column
df.drop(0, axis=0)            # Drop row by index
 
# Note: use | and & 

5. Mapping & Applying
df['col'].map(lambda x: x*2)             # Element-wise map (you can also use a dictionary) 
df['col'].apply(custom_func)            # Custom function
df.apply(func, axis=1)                  # Row-wise
df.applymap(str.upper)                  # Whole DataFrame

6. Cleaning Data
df.dropna()                  # Drop rows with NaN
df.fillna(0)                 # Fill NaNs
df['col'].str.strip()        # Remove whitespace
df['col'].astype(int)        # Convert type
df.duplicated().sum()        # Count duplicates
df.drop_duplicates()         # Remove duplicates

7. Grouping & Aggregating
df.groupby('col').mean()
df.groupby('col')['val'].sum()
df.pivot_table(index='A', columns='B', values='C', aggfunc='sum')

8. Merging & Joining
pd.concat([df1, df2])                       # Stack vertically
pd.merge(df1, df2, on='key')               # SQL-style join
pd.merge(df1, df2, how='left', on='key')   # Left join

9. Exporting
df.to_csv('output.csv', index=False)
df.to_excel('output.xlsx')

10. Useful Tricks
df['col'].value_counts()      # Count unique values
df.sort_values(by='col')      # Sort by column
df.sample(n=5)                # Random sample
df.reset_index(drop=True)     # Reset index
11. Group Data
grouped = data.groupby("GroupColumn")
â€œSplit data per unique value in GroupColumn.â€
âœ… Example:
Say your data looks like this:





























GroupColumnNumericalColumnA3A5B2B4A7
Would output:
A
  GroupColumn  NumericalColumn
0           A                3
1           A                5
4           A                7

B
  GroupColumn  NumericalColumn
2           B                2
3           B                4

The above output is produced by the code:
for group, group_data in data.groupby("GroupColumn"):
    print(group)
    print(group_data)

yggdrasil/Python-to-work-with-GZIP.title: Python to work with GZIP
yggdrasil/Python-to-work-with-GZIP.content:
Useful python to read and write to and from a gzip
import gzip
 
# Writing as text
with gzip.open('output.txt.gz', 'wt') as f:  # 'wt' = write text
    f.write("Hello, GZIP!\nThis is a test.")
 
# Writing as binary
with gzip.open('output.txt.gz', 'wb') as f:
    f.write(b"Binary data here\nAnother line")
 
import gzip
 
# Reading as text (e.g., CSV, JSON, etc.)
with gzip.open('file.txt.gz', 'rt') as f:  # 'rt' = read text
    for line in f:
        print(line.strip())
 
# Reading as binary
with gzip.open('file.txt.gz', 'rb') as f:

yggdrasil/REGENIE-(Complete).title: REGENIE (Complete)
yggdrasil/REGENIE-(Complete).content:
What it is
Essentially, it is a tool that allows you to test GWAS signals/genetic instrument associations while accounting for ancestry.
Some users have reported issues like inflated pâ€‘values under certain settingsâ€”though these often require careful QC and parameter tuning to resolve opensourcebiology.eu.sa
How it works
Imagine some dummy data for an organism that has 4 genes
Individual A has a trait and mutant genetic variants of genes 2, 3, and 4.
Individual B has the same trait and the same genetic variants on genes 3 and 4.
There are other individuals also, such that they model the data below:

































GenotypeTrait123412340.81340.9120.110.2This could lead us to believe that the genetic variants on genes 3 and 4 are responsible for the trait, but in reality the trait on gene 4 is a covariate because A and B are related.
If we just did a simple association test for gene 4 now, we would be lead to think that gene 4 is causally related to the trait. The issue is that we donâ€™t have a data point for genotype 1, 2, 3. We also donâ€™t have a datapoint with just genotype 4.
Note, even if we did have these, that would not solve the true problem, as in reality we likely have 100s of genes that each contribute a little, and thus we have small values for all of them. However, for the purposes of this example, letâ€™s continue with 4 genes.
But we can use the statistics from rest of the population to essentially predict how a person with genotype 1, 2, 3 would show the trait. This is the polygenic risk score prediction.
To do this, we first calculate the risk of 1, 2, 3 using statistics magic. Suppose this yields an association score of 0.8.
Now genotype gene 4â€™s association with the trait is calculated from all of the other genotypes, which include 1, 2, 3 and comes up with an association score of 0.8. But this test included the genotypes 1, 2, 3, and many others with those genes. We adjust for them with the earlier 0.8, since we have their association with the trait. This shows us that 4 actually does not correlate with the trait.
When we do the same thing the other way around, genotype 1, 2, 4 would give 0.2, and genotype 1, 2, 3, 4 would give 0.80, and adjusted for the effects of genotype 1, 2, 4, 3 would give still give 0.6. This shows that 3 is actually related.
There is a problem when both contribute significantly, e.g. 3, and 4, 0.8, and 0.8. This is not handled by Regenie.
Statistics Magic
This is the calculation of the polygenic risk score.

yggdrasil/Sea-Born's-Data-Visualisation-.title: Sea Born's Data Visualisation Code
yggdrasil/Sea-Born's-Data-Visualisation-.content:
To import sea born, use
import seaborn 
 
To plot a histogram, use
seaborn.histplot(data = data, x="Name of Column with numerical value", hue="Name of y axis variable", binwidth = 2, multiple="stack") 
seaborn.histplot() takes data as a pandas table, and subsequent arguments are the column names. x is a column name, and the hue is also a column name. binwidth is self explaining and multiple="stack" is an optional argument showing that the data parts need to be stacked.
import seaborn as sns
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
 
# Plot the histogram
sns.histplot(data=data, x="Name of Column with numerical value", hue="Name of y axis variable", binwidth=2, multiple="stack")
 
# Mean line
mean_value = data["Name of Column with numerical value"].mean()
plt.axvline(mean_value, color='red', linestyle='dashed', linewidth=2, label=f'Mean: {mean_value:.2f}')
 
# Move legend outside to the right
plt.legend(loc='upper left', bbox_to_anchor=(1, 1))
 
# Adjust layout so the legend isn't cut off
plt.tight_layout()
 
# Show plot
plt.show()

yggdrasil/VCF-(Complete).title: VCF (Complete)
yggdrasil/VCF-(Complete).content:
ğŸ§¬ What is a VCF File?
VCF stands for Variant Call Format. Itâ€™s a standard text file format used in bioinformatics to store genetic variant dataâ€”like SNPs (single nucleotide polymorphisms), insertions, deletions, and structural variantsâ€”detected from sequencing data.

ğŸ“¦ VCF File Structure
A typical VCF file has two main sections:


Header (starts with ## or #)


Data Records (tab-delimited columns)



1. ğŸ“ Header


Starts with multiple ## metadata lines (e.g. info about reference genome, filters, formats).


The final header line begins with #CHROM and defines the column names.


Example:
##fileformat=VCFv4.2
##INFO=<ID=DP,Number=1,Type=Integer,Description="Total Depth">
##FORMAT=<ID=GT,Number=1,Type=String,Description="Genotype">
#CHROM POS ID REF ALT QUAL FILTER INFO FORMAT Sample1 Sample2

2. ğŸ”¢ Data Rows
Each line is a variant record with at least these columns:

















































ColumnMeaningCHROMChromosomePOSPosition on the chromosomeIDVariant ID (e.g., dbSNP rsID)REFReference alleleALTAlternate allele(s)QUALQuality score of the variantFILTERFilter status (e.g., PASS)INFOKey-value pairs with extra detailsFORMATHow to interpret sample columnsSample(s)Genotype data per individual
Example:
chr1  1234567  rs123456  G  A  50  PASS  DP=100  GT  0/1  1/1

ğŸ” INFO and FORMAT Fields
These are semicolon- or colon-delimited fields holding detailed info:


INFO=DP=100: Depth of reads


FORMAT=GT:AD: Genotype, Allelic Depth


Sample1=0/1:35,65: Heterozygous with 35 REF reads and 65 ALT reads



ğŸ“ File Extensions


.vcf: plain text


.vcf.gz: compressed version (bgzip + tabix index)



ğŸ›  Tools That Use VCFs


bcftools, vcftools â€“ for manipulating VCFs


PLINK (Complete), GATK, SAMtools â€“ common in pipelines


ANNOVAR, VEP â€“ for annotating variants

yggdrasil/bed-file-format.title: bed file format
yggdrasil/bed-file-format.content:
The .bed format is a binary file format that can be generated using Plink2. It can also be generated from plink1.9, though this is not something that you have tried before.
Download PLINK 2 should help you with generating a .bed from .bgen using PLINK2.

yggdrasil/polygenic-risk-score.title: polygenic risk score
yggdrasil/polygenic-risk-score.content:
TLDR?
A polygenic risk score (PRS) is a way to estimate an individualâ€™s genetic predisposition to a certain trait or disease by combining the effects of many genetic variants across the genome.

ğŸ”¬ What Is It?
A PRS summarizes the cumulative effect of many single-nucleotide polymorphisms (SNPs), each of which contributes a small amount to the risk of a complex trait (like heart disease, diabetes, height, or intelligence).

ğŸ§® How Is It Calculated?
At a high level, the formula looks like this:
PRS=âˆ‘i=1nÎ²iâ‹…Gi\text{PRS} = \sum_{i=1}^{n} \beta_i \cdot G_i
Where:


Î²i\beta_i: Effect size (log-odds or regression coefficient) of SNP ii, typically from a GWAS summary statistics file


GiG_i: The individualâ€™s genotype at SNP ii, usually encoded as 0, 1, or 2 copies of the risk allele


nn: Number of SNPs included in the score (often filtered by p-value, LD pruning, etc.)



ğŸ› ï¸ Steps to Calculate PRS


Get GWAS Summary Statistics
From a large, high-quality genome-wide association study (GWAS), download effect sizes (usually beta or odds ratio), p-values, and SNP IDs.


Quality Control & Filtering


Remove ambiguous SNPs (e.g., A/T or C/G)


Apply p-value threshold (e.g., p<1eâˆ’5p < 1e-5) or use all SNPs


Perform LD pruning to reduce correlation between nearby SNPs




Match SNPs to Genotype Data

Make sure the SNPs in the GWAS summary stats match those in your individual-level genotype dataset (e.g., PLINK .bed/.bim/.fam files)



Calculate the Weighted Sum


For each SNP: multiply the number of risk alleles (0, 1, 2) by the GWAS effect size


Sum over all selected SNPs to get the individualâ€™s raw PRS




Standardize the Score (optional)


You can z-score normalize across individuals in the cohort:
zPRSi=PRSiâˆ’Î¼Ïƒ\text{zPRS}_i = \frac{\text{PRS}_i - \mu}{\sigma}
where Î¼\mu and Ïƒ\sigma are the mean and standard deviation across individuals





ğŸ§  Example
Say we use 3 SNPs:

























SNPEffect Size (Î²)Genotype (G)rs10.122rs2-0.081rs30.200
Then:
PRS=(0.12Ã—2)+(âˆ’0.08Ã—1)+(0.20Ã—0)=0.24âˆ’0.08+0=0.16\text{PRS} = (0.12 \times 2) + (-0.08 \times 1) + (0.20 \times 0) = 0.24 - 0.08 + 0 = 0.16

ğŸ§° Common Tools


PLINK: Widely used for genotype handling and PRS calculation


PRSice: Automates PRS calculation and clumping


LDpred: Bayesian method that adjusts effect sizes for LD


scikit-learn or R for custom pipelines and machine learning on PRS



âš ï¸ Notes & Limitations


PRS performance depends heavily on the ancestry match between your target individual and the GWAS cohort.


Environmental and lifestyle factors arenâ€™t captured.


Some diseases are oligogenic or monogenic, not suitable for PRS.
